i'm also trying to cut down my hate reading, even with subjects like music and other pop culture. there's no good point in getting worked up about someone else's opinion to the point that you're constantly mad online

i found i was partially to blame for my own woes on here by participating in the negativity. i've mostly cut that out and it's a better world. i no longer reply to obviously baiting fb comments. i don't engage with bad people

also! if you find yourself increasingly dismayed with your time on social media, think about what you are doing to add to your own negativity. are you constantly quote tweeting racists and replying to bad takes?
i unfollowed a bunch on here and fb, muted words/people, curated my feed so it's just what i need to see to make my experience enjoyable. i 90% stopped tweeting about news. i have 90% less dread now
your social media experience is what YOU make of it. it doesn't have to be toxic, and you don't have to delete your accounts

To everyone who came down to watch #CrazyRichAsians with @SimuLiu and I yesterday, THANK YOU! We sold the place out. We laughed hard. We cheered loud. We cried together. We saw ourselves on the big screen. We witnessed history. If you missed out, please go see the movie!

#CrazyRichAsians made me think of my own experience being raised by a single mother and how that gave me the strength I have today. So, I wanted to especially celebrate all the single mothers and women whose stories are beautifully centered in this film.
I just want to give a shoutout to all of the Asian American journalists and critics who have written and pushed for stories on #CrazyRichAsians. You are the unsung heroes of the movement. Thank you.

I’m seeing the #seizure warning go out for #Incredibles2, and with it a fair number of “just close your eyes”.

For photosensitive #epilepsy, this advice isn’t just useless, it’s harmful. Light filtering through the (red) capillaries of the eyelids *increases* seizure risk.
